question:
A security team wants to limit access to specific services or actions in all of the team's AWS accounts. All accounts belong to a large organization in AWS Organizations. The solution must be scalable and there must be a single point where permissions can be maintained.
What should a solutions architect do to accomplish this?

options.A: Create an ACL to provide access to the services or actions.
options.B: Create a security group to allow accounts and attach it to user groups.
options.C: Create cross-account roles in each account to deny access to the services or actions.
options.D: Create a service control policy in the root organizational unit to deny access to the services or actions.

explanation: Service Control Policies (SCPs) in AWS Organizations provide centralized control over permissions across all accounts. SCPs attached to the root OU apply to all accounts, providing a single point of management. This is scalable and doesn't require per-account configuration.
